title: NixOS Package PRs for nixos, coreutils-full-9.1, pcsclite-with-polkit-1.9.5, alsa-utils, NetworkManager-openconnect, xsetroot packages
description: NixOS Package PRs for nixos, coreutils-full-9.1, pcsclite-with-polkit-1.9.5, alsa-utils, NetworkManager-openconnect, xsetroot packages on GitHub

items.content_html:
Description of changes

This PR adds my stupid package that compares the current and latest NixOS generations and creates a file to let you know if you "need" to reboot or not.

  • Built on platform(s)
    • x86_64-linux
    • aarch64-linux
    • x86_64-darwin
    • aarch64-darwin
  • For non-Linux: Is sandboxing enabled in nix.conf? (See Nix manual)
    • sandbox = relaxed
    • sandbox = true
  • Tested, as applicable:
    • NixOS test(s) (look inside nixos/tests)
    • and/or package tests
    • or, for functions and "core" functionality, tests in lib/tests or pkgs/test
    • made sure NixOS tests are linked to the relevant packages
  • Tested compilation of all packages that depend on this change using nix-shell -p nixpkgs-review --run "nixpkgs-review rev HEAD". Note: all changes have to be committed, also see nixpkgs-review usage

items.title: nixos/tailscale-derper: init

items.content_html:
The added tests ensure that nixos-version --json and nixos-version --configuration-revision return the git revision set via system.configurationRevision.

I erroneously opened #303945, because I thought this functionality was broken, but I had just removed system.configurationRevision from my config by mistake.
The test ensures this functionality is working as intended.

Description of changes

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Added a new services.tomcat.port option to provide the ability to change the default listen port.

Modified the test so that it tests this new option.

I've wanted this feature because there's quite a lot of programs that wants port 8080.

items.title: nixos/tomcat: add 'port' option

items.content_html:
Description of changes

This brings two benefits. For one thing, it exposes the generated config file which users can build separately to validate it. For another, it allows users to provide their own config file.

Closes: #313777

items.title: nixos/ejabberd: support rfc42 style options

items.content_html:
Allow users to disable the shadow authentication suite.

My primary motivation is to reduce the attack surface of setuid binaries, by removing them where possible. shadow understandably introduces many setuid binaries. I realised, however, that I don't use any of these.

The test demonstrates login working without needing the shadow suite.

Description of changes

Things done

  • Built on platform(s)
    • x86_64-linux
    • aarch64-linux
    • x86_64-darwin
    • aarch64-darwin
  • For non-Linux: Is sandboxing enabled in nix.conf? (See Nix manual)
    • sandbox = relaxed
    • sandbox = true
  • Tested, as applicable:
    • NixOS test(s) (look inside nixos/tests)
    • and/or package tests
    • or, for functions and "core" functionality, tests in lib/tests or pkgs/test
    • made sure NixOS tests are linked to the relevant packages
  • Tested compilation of all packages that depend on this change using nix-shell -p nixpkgs-review --run "nixpkgs-review rev HEAD". Note: all changes have to be committed, also see nixpkgs-review usage
  • Tested basic functionality of all binary files (usually in ./result/bin/)
  • 24.05 Release Notes (or backporting 23.05 and 23.11 Release notes)
    • (Package updates) Added a release notes entry if the change is major or breaking
    • (Module updates) Added a release notes entry if the change is significant
    • (Module addition) Added a release notes entry if adding a new NixOS module
  • Fits CONTRIBUTING.md.

items.title: nixos/shadow: introduce security.shadow.enable
